title: Bug: Spatial query additional operations still overflowing
description: The blocks container in the spatial query builder still appears to overflow despite adding max-h-40 and overflow-y-auto classes. The scrollable container may not be working as expected. Need to verify the HTML structure and ensure the scrollbar appears when there are many blocks.

title: Implement all block operators (Near point, Touches boundary, Inside boundary, Operator, Mode)
description: Translate each operator type from builder blocks into correct SQL: Near point → ST_DWithin or bbox expansion, Touches boundary → ST_Touches, Inside boundary → ST_Within, Operator exclusion → WHERE operator = ?, Mode exclusion → WHERE mode = ?. Handle Include/Also Include/Exclude logic combination (AND/OR/NOT). Add tests for each operator. Dependencies: SQL generator + runner.

title: SLB-04 Evidence output integration
description:
Scope
- Use runner output to generate plain-English logic sentence.
- Attach block parameters + template metadata to Evidence panel and exports.
- Ensure share/state encoding includes SLB parameters if supported.

Notes
- Align with SQ-08 evidence requirements; avoid duplication.

title: SLB-01 Builder UI shell + state model
description:
Scope
- Add Simplified Spatial Logic Builder panel UI (Include / Also include / Exclude blocks) aligned with design mockup at public/design/index.html.
- Define builder state model in state/manager.js (blocks, ordering, constraints, active/disabled states).
- Wire UI controls to state setters only; no direct mutations.

Notes
- Keep UI visual and guided; no boolean terminology displayed.
- Logic compilation handled in SLB-02/SLB-03.
notes: Builder UI shell complete with all requirements met: panel renders in index.html with Include/Also Include/Exclude pills, blocks container with add/remove/reorder capability, state model in spatial/builder.js (438 lines), plain-English summary, no boolean terminology, Clear button resets state. Block operators implemented with structured dropdowns (Near point, Touches boundary, Inside boundary for Include; Operator/Mode for Exclude). Compilation to query object works via compile() function. Execution blocked by runner stub.

title: Wire or hide non-functional tabs and layer toggles
description:

Context:

- Layers panel checkboxes in public/index.html are static; no listeners in public/app.js.

Acceptance criteria:

- If disabled, use aria-disabled and tooltip copy explaining status.

Files:

- public/app.js (if wiring)
- public/js/map/utils.js (if layer visibility handlers added)

title: Filter controls inconsistent (auto-fit jumping, Clear leaves empty table, map filter sometimes not applied)
description:
User reports weird filter behaviour. Audit each control: Mode/Operator/Time band (multi-select), LA/RPT (single), service search, viewport limit checkbox, Clear/Reset.

Problems observed in code:
- Any filter apply triggers fitMapToScope(), which is jarring once filters auto-apply on change.
- Clear/Reset currently empties table/stats and does not reload full dataset.
- Map filter can be a no-op when selected filters exist but tileFields have not been detected (buildMapFilter returns null).

Expected:
- Changing filter controls updates map + table consistently.
- Auto-apply on change should not re-fit map each time (only on explicit Apply if desired).
- Clear/Reset restores full dataset counts/table.
- Map filtering should retry tile-field detection when filters are set.

title: Epic: Spatial Query Tool (Point + Boundary)
description:
Summary
Add a Spatial Query Tool to the Map Viewer that lets users place a point, define a boundary (radius/polygon/admin area), apply boolean spatial logic, and update map/table/evidence.

Goals
- Answer spatial questions in under a minute for non-GIS users
- Keep interaction visual and intuitive
- Make outputs defensible and reproducible

Non-goals (v1)
- Editing route geometry
- Complex multi-shape operations beyond defined boolean options
- Full GIS buffering UI (keep simple/opinionated)

Dependencies
- Stable service_id + mode/operator attributes
- DuckDB-WASM initialised
- Map highlighting/filtering by service_id
- LA/RPT clip available if boundary option enabled

Source: Feature request (Spatial Query Tool)

Template source should be driven by the Python runner so updates don’t require UI rewrites; design for future user-defined templates.

title: Map misses scope-selected service
description:
## Summary
Selecting a specific service via the scope search updates the results table correctly, but the map still renders the full dataset instead of highlighting the scoped service. The UI needs to keep the map and table in sync when scope search restricts to one service.

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Run scope search for a known service (e.g., serviceId X).
2. Observe table shows filtered rows.
3. Map still shows every route instead of the single selected service.

## Expected
Map layer filters to the scoped service(s) and highlights them, matching the table output.

## Actual
Map still renders all routes; there is no filtering/fire update when the scope search result changes.

## Context
Likely related to spatial query or table-state synchronization; map filters may not be re-applied when scope search updates the scoped service selection. Ensure MapLibre filter uses latest scope/service selection before rendering.

## Dependencies
- Could involve NetworkView-3uh if scope search is reused there.

title: Phase 4: Add smoke tests
description:
Phase: Phase 4 — Performance hardening + real time bands (as data allows) (ongoing)
Source: plan.md
Details:
- “LA clip returns expected counts”
- “Operator filter yields stable totals”

Additional scope: add lightweight diagnostic logging for key user actions and error paths so smoke tests can verify expected telemetry and failure modes.

title: Phase 1: Extract Core Domain (Pure Logic)
description:
## Goal

Create pure domain modules for spatial queries WITHOUT changing existing code. This phase is LOW RISK - we're only adding new modules, not modifying anything.

## Estimated Effort

4-6 hours

## What to Build

Create 3 new modules in `public/js/spatial/core/`:

### 1. query.js - Domain Model

**Purpose:** Pure data structure for spatial queries

**Key Features:**
- SpatialQuery class with constructor
- toJSON() / fromJSON() for serialization
- describe() for human-readable description
- No dependencies on global state or DOM

**Example:**
```javascript
export class SpatialQuery {
  constructor({ find, condition, distance, target, blocks = [] }) {
    this.find = find;
    this.condition = condition;
    this.distance = distance;
    this.target = target;
    this.blocks = blocks;
  }
  
  toJSON() { /* serialize */ }
  static fromJSON(obj) { /* deserialize */ }
  describe() { /* human-readable string */ }
}
```

### 2. validator.js - Validation Logic

**Purpose:** Validate queries before execution

**Key Features:**
- validateQuery(query, context) returns array of error strings
- assertValid(query, context) throws ValidationError
- Context includes { point, boundary, spatialReady }
- Validation rules:
  - Required fields (find, target, distance >= 0)
  - Target-specific (point required for selected_point)
  - Block validation (type, operator, value)
  - Controlled impurity accepted (checks spatialReady)

**Example:**
```javascript
export const validateQuery = (query, context = {}) => {
  const errors = [];
  if (!query.find) errors.push("'find' is required");
  if (query.target === "selected_point" && !context.point) {
    errors.push("Point required for selected_point target");
  }
  // ... more validation
  return errors;
};
```

### 3. compiler.js - Query Compilation

**Purpose:** Transform query to execution format

**Key Features:**
- compileQuery(query, context) returns compiled object
- Versioned contract (semver: "1.0.0")
- Hash for caching (hashQuery helper)
- Metadata includes compilation context
- Calls assertValid() before compiling

**Example:**
```javascript
export const compileQuery = (query, context = {}) => {
  assertValid(query, context);
  
  return {
    version: "1.0.0",
    find: query.find,
    blocks: [/* transformed blocks */],
    metadata: { compiled_at, context },
    hash: hashQuery(query)
  };
};
```

## Refactoring Practices

**CRITICAL - Follow AGENTS.md:**

1. **Do NOT modify existing code** - Only create new files
2. **Backup before starting:**
   ```bash
   cp -r public/js/spatial /tmp/spatial_backup
   ```

3. **Test-driven development:**
   - Write tests FIRST in tests/spatial-core.test.js
   - Aim for 100% coverage on these modules
   - Run `npm test -- spatial-core` after each function

4. **No global state access:**
   - No `import { state }` from state/manager.js
   - All dependencies via parameters
   - Pure functions only (except validation context checks)

5. **Document controlled impurity:**
   ```javascript
   // NOTE: This validation has controlled impurity - it checks
   // context.spatialReady which is infrastructure state.
   // This is acceptable because spatial availability is a
   // runtime infrastructure concern.
   ```

6. **Git workflow:**
   ```bash
   git checkout -b spatial-refactor-phase1
   
   # Commit each module separately
   git add public/js/spatial/core/query.js tests/spatial-core.test.js
   git commit -m "Add SpatialQuery domain model with tests"
   
   git add public/js/spatial/core/validator.js tests/spatial-validator.test.js
   git commit -m "Add query validation with comprehensive tests"
   
   git add public/js/spatial/core/compiler.js tests/spatial-compiler.test.js
   git commit -m "Add query compiler with caching and versioning"
   ```

## Testing Strategy

**Target: 100% coverage for core domain**

Test files to create:
- tests/spatial-core.test.js (query model)
- tests/spatial-validator.test.js (validation)
- tests/spatial-compiler.test.js (compilation)

**Test scenarios:**

Query Model:
- Constructor sets properties correctly
- toJSON() serializes all fields
- fromJSON() deserializes correctly
- describe() generates readable string
- Handles blocks array

Validator:
- Required field validation
- Distance validation (non-negative, number)
- Target-specific validation (point, boundary)
- Block validation (type, operator, value)
- Returns empty array for valid query
- Returns multiple errors for invalid query

Compiler:
- Validates before compiling
- Throws ValidationError for invalid query
- Returns versioned contract
- Includes compilation metadata
- Hash is stable for same query
- Hash differs for different queries

**Run tests:**
```bash
npm test -- spatial-core
npm test -- spatial-validator  
npm test -- spatial-compiler

# Verify 100% coverage
npm run test:coverage
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] public/js/spatial/core/query.js created with SpatialQuery class
- [ ] public/js/spatial/core/validator.js created with validation functions
- [ ] public/js/spatial/core/compiler.js created with compilation logic
- [ ] tests/spatial-core.test.js with 100% coverage of query.js
- [ ] tests/spatial-validator.test.js with 100% coverage of validator.js
- [ ] tests/spatial-compiler.test.js with 100% coverage of compiler.js
- [ ] All new tests passing (npm test)
- [ ] No changes to existing code (git diff shows only new files)
- [ ] Documentation added to each module (JSDoc comments)
- [ ] Committed and pushed to branch spatial-refactor-phase1

## No Breaking Changes

This phase should NOT affect existing functionality:
- Existing spatial queries still work
- builder.js unchanged
- runner.js unchanged
- app.js unchanged
- All 34 existing tests still pass

## References

- SPATIAL_ARCHITECTURE_REVIEW.md sections: "Core Domain Models"
- AGENTS.md section: "Code Housekeeping & Structure Requirements"

## Parent Epic

NetworkView-p5s (Spatial Query Module: Architectural Refactoring)
notes: Phase 1 complete. Created core domain modules (query, validator, compiler) with 100% test coverage (39 tests). No changes to existing code. All existing tests still pass (190 total). Ready for Phase 2.

State management in place via spatial/builder.js (438 lines). Feature flag spatialQuery enabled in config files. Execution pipeline still pending (runner is stub).

title: Spatial Query Module: Architectural Refactoring
description:
## Problem Statement

Current spatial module has architectural brittleness where "every fix breaks something." 

**Core Issues:**
- Unclear separation of concerns (builder.js does UI + logic + state)
- Complex state dependencies (4 overlapping state objects)
- Tight coupling to global state
- Missing validation layer
- Brittle integration points
- Execution flow confusion

**Impact:**
- Development friction (unpredictable time to add features)
- High regression rate (~40% of changes break existing features)
- Difficult to test (modules depend on global state, DOM)
- Blocks SLB epic (NetworkView-1tt)

## Solution

Refactor to layered architecture with clear separation of concerns:

**Layers:**
```
Presentation (UI only) → Application (orchestration) → Domain (pure logic) → Infrastructure (SQL/DB)
```

**7 Key Principles:**
1. Clear layer separation
2. Single source of truth (one state.spatial object)
3. Unidirectional data flow
4. Dependency inversion (inject dependencies, not global access)
5. Explicit execution model (cancellable, versioned queries)
6. Strong validation (fail fast at boundaries)
7. Loose coupling via events (fan-out only, not core logic)

**Architecture Decisions:**
- Controlled impurity accepted at boundaries (spatial rules need context)
- Cancellation support - "latest result wins" for concurrent edits
- Query caching - hash-based cache for performance
- Versioned contracts - compiled queries are stable, serializable
- Events for side effects only - core execution stays synchronous/debuggable

## Approach

**Parallel Operation Strategy:**
- No big-bang rewrite
- Run old and new architecture side-by-side
- Feature flag: config.features.spatial_new_architecture
- Compatibility shims for gradual cutover
- Comprehensive testing at each phase
- Only remove old code after new is proven

## Success Metrics

**Architectural Health:**
- Coupling: <20% modules with global state access (currently ~80%)
- Test Coverage: >90% (currently ~50%)
- Cyclomatic Complexity: <10 per function (builder.js has >15)

**Developer Experience:**
- Time to add feature: <2h (currently unpredictable)
- Regression rate: <10% (currently ~40%)

## References

- SPATIAL_ARCHITECTURE_REVIEW.md - Complete architectural analysis
- AGENTS.md - Refactoring guidelines
- plan.md - Discovery log

## Phases

See child tasks for detailed phase breakdown (6 phases, 34-48h total)

title: Improve spatial builder UI clarity and terminology
description:
Make the spatial query builder more intuitive by clarifying what Include/Exclude/Or Include actually do.

Issues:
- "Additional Logic:" label was unclear
- Button labels didn't clearly indicate their boolean logic (AND/OR/NOT)
- No explanation of how the refine operations work
- Users unsure what each button does

Scope:
- Rename "Additional Logic:" to something clearer
- Change "Also Include" to better indicate OR logic
- Add help tooltip explaining the three operations
- Make summary text use plain English (AND, OR, BUT NOT)

Acceptance:
- Users understand what each button does without reading documentation
- Clear distinction between Include (AND), Or Include (OR), and Exclude (NOT)
- Help available on hover for quick reference

title: Implement dynamic operator/mode dropdowns in spatial builder
description:
Replace hardcoded operator/mode dropdown values with dynamic population from state.metadata.

Scope:
- Pull actual operators from state.metadata.operators
- Pull actual modes from state.metadata.modes  
- Normalize data formats to handle both string arrays and object arrays
- Rebuild dropdowns when switching between operator/mode types
- Add fallback values for when metadata hasn't loaded yet

Acceptance:
- Exclude block value dropdowns show real operators/modes from loaded dataset
- Dropdowns update dynamically when switching between "by Operator" and "by Mode"
- No hardcoded operator/mode lists remain in builder code
- Console logging helps debug metadata loading timing issues

Integration notes:
- Uses same normalization logic as app.js for consistency
- Mirrors operator/mode data structures used elsewhere in application
notes:
Implemented dynamic operator/mode dropdown population in spatial query builder.

Changes made to public/js/spatial/builder.js:

1. Added state import:
   - import { state, setSpatialBuilder } from "../state/manager.js"

2. Added data normalization functions (mirroring app.js logic):
   - normalizeModes(raw) - handles both string arrays and object arrays
   - normalizeOperators(raw) - extracts code/label from various formats

3. Added metadata accessor functions:
   - getAvailableOperators() - pulls from state.metadata.operators with fallback
   - getAvailableModes() - pulls from state.metadata.modes with fallback
   - Both include console logging for debugging

4. Created dynamic dropdown builder:
   - buildValueSelectOptions(operatorType) - generates HTML for operator/mode select
   - Handles both operator objects {code, label} and plain mode strings
   - Includes placeholder "Select operator/mode..." option

5. Updated getOperatorOptions():
   - Exclude blocks now use buildValueSelectOptions(currentOperator)
   - Dynamically rebuilds based on whether operator or mode is selected

6. Enhanced operator change handler:
   - Detects when switching between "operator" and "mode" types
   - Rebuilds value dropdown with appropriate data
   - Resets value when switching types to prevent stale selections

Files modified:
- public/js/spatial/builder.js (lines 1-200+)

Testing:
- Syntax verified with node -c command
- Console logs added for metadata loading debugging
- Fallback values ensure UI works even if metadata loads slowly

Implementation complete and ready for browser testing.

title: SLB-02 Template library + Python runner integration
description:
Scope
- Integrate Python-backed runner to compile builder blocks into internal boolean logic + metadata.
- Define template inputs/outputs (JSON schema) for templates and runner responses.
- Ensure UI uses runner output (no hard-coded logic).

Notes
- Runner should support updating templates without UI changes; future user-defined templates should be possible.

title: SLB-06 Tests (builder state, compilation, evidence)
description:
Scope
- Unit tests for builder state model and constraints.
- Tests for runner output handling + plain-English sentence generation.
- Integration tests for map/table updates if feasible.

Notes

Should have fallback to bbox calculations if ST_ functions unavailable. Dependencies: DuckDB spatial extension resolution (NetworkView-3uh.1).

title: Accessibility: status live region + icon button labels
description:
Status and control affordances are not fully accessible. The status text updates are not announced to screen readers, and several icon-only buttons rely on title text only.

Context:
- Status element: #status in public/index.html updates frequently via setStatus in public/app.js.
- Icon-only buttons: sidebar fullscreen, data inspector filter/expand, close buttons in mock panels.

Acceptance criteria:
- Add aria-live (polite) and role="status" to the status region.
- Add aria-labels to icon-only buttons (filter toggle, expand table, sidebar fullscreen, mock close buttons).
- Ensure focus styles are visible on keyboard navigation for key controls.

Files:
- public/index.html
- public/styles.css (if needed for focus styles)

title: Implement spatial query runner with DuckDB execution
description: Replace stub in public/js/spatial/runner.js with working implementation. Runner must: accept compiled builder state + point + DuckDB instance, generate SQL via sql.js, execute query against routes table, return serviceIds array + count, handle errors gracefully. Wire to builder onRun event in app.js. Dependencies: SQL generator (NetworkView-1tt.6).

notes: Fixed by calling populateBoundaryFilters after initDuckDb; added app wiring and map-utils tests to cover LA/RPT filter behavior.

title: SQ-06 Map highlighting + dim non-matching routes

Scope

Acceptance

title: When a map feature is cliced on the map it should be highliighted and prioritied in the table view
description:
Feature: Map selection sync with table view

Summary
When a user clicks a feature on the map, that feature is visually highlighted and brought to the top of the table view.

User need
Users want to quickly see more detail about a map feature without having to search for it in a long table.

Behaviour

Clicking a feature on the map selects it.

The selected feature is highlighted on the map using a clear visual state.

The same feature is highlighted in the table view.

The table automatically reorders so the selected feature appears at the top.

If multiple features are already sorted, the selected feature remains pinned above the existing sort order.

Clicking a different map feature updates both the map highlight and the table position.

Clicking away clears the selection and returns the table to its previous order.

Interaction notes

Highlighting should be subtle and consistent across map and table.

The interaction should feel instant, with no visible reload of the table.

Keyboard and touch interactions should behave the same way as mouse clicks.

Value
This reduces cognitive load, speeds up inspection of data, and keeps map and table views clearly in sync.

title: Multi-select defaults filter table to (none); map/table out of sync
description:
Repro: load app with metadata-driven multi-select filters (Mode/Operator). Browser auto-selects the first option, which is '(none)', causing buildWhere() to apply an unknown-only filter => queryCount returns 0 and Data Inspector shows 'Rows 0–0 of 0' even though routes render on the map.

Also: changing Mode/Operator/LA/RPT/Time band should immediately apply filters (map + table), but only some controls auto-apply today.

Expected: On first load, no filter is applied by default (multi-selects start with no selection), initial table loads all routes, and changing any filter control updates the map/table consistently.

Bug: Tooltips not working on spatial query action pills
description: The title attributes added to the Include/Also Include/Exclude action pills in the spatial query builder are not displaying tooltips on hover. Need to investigate if this is a browser/CSS issue or if we need to implement a custom tooltip solution.
notes:
Fixed by implementing CSS tooltips using Tailwind group-hover pattern instead of native title attributes.

Changes made to public/index.html (lines 293-324):
- Added help icon with tooltip explaining Include (AND), Or Include (OR), Exclude (NOT) logic
- Added individual tooltips to all three action buttons (Include, Or Include, Exclude)
- Used invisible group-hover:visible pattern with absolute positioning
- Tooltips appear on hover with dark background and clear explanations

Implementation uses pure CSS (no JavaScript) and is accessible. Tooltips work correctly on hover.

Files modified:

title: BUG: Simple filters return no results after spatial logic changes
description:
Symptoms
- Mode/operator/LA/RPT filters no longer change table/map after recent spatial logic work.
- With spatial logic active or inactive, Apply Filters appears to run but dataset remains full or empty unexpectedly.

Notes
- Likely tied to serviceIds/serviceIdsActive gating or spatialQuery state not being cleared/disabled properly.
- Reported after spatial query integration and point picker changes.

Repro
1) Open app.
2) Select mode BUS and click Apply Filters.
3) Observe table/map not filtered.

Expected
- Table/map only show matching routes for selected mode/operator/area.

Actual
- No change (or empty) despite filters applied.

Files to inspect
- public/app.js (getCurrentFilters, onApplyFilters)
- public/js/filters/builder.js (serviceIdsActive handling)
- public/js/map/utils.js (serviceIdsActive handling)
- public/js/state/manager.js (spatialQuery state lifecycle)
notes:
Additional fix applied to prevent empty spatial queries from blocking other filters:

Modified public/js/state/manager.js setSpatialMatchSet() function (lines 160-179):
- Changed logic to only set active: true when ids.length > 0
- Empty spatial queries now set active: false
- This prevents empty match sets from applying WHERE FALSE and blocking attribute filters

Root cause: When spatial builder was initialized or reset, it would set an empty match set with active: true, causing serviceIdsActive to block all results even when spatial query wasn't being used.

Fix ensures spatial query state is properly inactive when no service IDs are matched.

title: Documentation

title: Simplify left-panel filtering tiers
description:
## Summary
The left-panel filters currently expose a flat list of modes/operators/LA/RPT selectors plus the new spatial query builder, resulting in overwhelming complexity. We should rationalize that control surface so users can progressively create layered filters (mode → operator → LA → RPT) similar to how spatial query blocks stack. Consider allowing additive/subtractive modules or a filtering palette that mirrors the spatial builder state hierarchy and lets users experiment with combinations without digging through every control for each layer.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Document the existing filtering hierarchy (modes → operators → LA → RPT) and identify opportunities for progressive disclosure or a modular builder that can add/remove layers.
- Design or prototype a unified filtering module (could be a modal, flyout, or builder row/stack) enabling users to define hierarchical filters without exposing every control simultaneously.
- Ensure the new design integrates cleanly with the spatial query builder (possibly reusing the block metaphor) and keeps the map/table in sync.
- Update documentation and AGENTS/plan notes about the chosen filing approach before implementation begins.

## Dependencies
- Ties into NetworkView-3uh for spatial integration; also overlaps with existing filter pipelines in public/js/filters/builder.js

title: Phase 6: Testing & Documentation (>90% Coverage)
description:
## Goal

Achieve comprehensive test coverage and documentation for new spatial architecture. This is LOW RISK - adding quality assurance.

## Estimated Effort

6-8 hours

## What to Build

### 1. Comprehensive Test Suite

**Target: >90% coverage for all spatial modules**

**Test Levels:**

#### Unit Tests (Pure Logic)
```
tests/spatial/core/
├── query.test.js         (SpatialQuery model)
├── validator.test.js     (validation rules)
└── compiler.test.js      (compilation logic)

tests/spatial/infrastructure/
├── sql-builder.test.js   (SQL generation)
└── duckdb-runner.test.js (query execution)

tests/spatial/application/
├── event-bus.test.js     (event emitter)
├── executor.test.js      (execution orchestration)
└── spatial-service.test.js (service layer)

tests/spatial/ui/
├── builder-ui.test.js    (UI components)
└── builder-state.test.js (UI state)
```

#### Integration Tests
```
tests/spatial/integration/
├── query-flow.test.js      (validate → compile → execute)
├── concurrency.test.js     (cancellation, latest wins)
├── caching.test.js         (query cache behavior)
└── state-sync.test.js      (state consistency)
```

#### E2E Tests (Playwright)
```
tests/e2e/spatial/
├── point-query.e2e.js      (Click map → set distance → run)
├── block-operators.e2e.js  (Add/remove blocks)
├── error-handling.e2e.js   (Invalid queries)
└── performance.e2e.js      (Query execution time)
```

### 2. Coverage Targets

**Overall: >90%**
- Core domain: 100% (pure logic, easy to test)
- Infrastructure: >90% (mock DB, test SQL)
- Application: >85% (mock dependencies)
- UI: >80% (DOM testing is slower)

**Run coverage:**
```bash
npm run test:coverage

# Should show:
# File                     | % Stmts | % Branch | % Funcs | % Lines
# -------------------------|---------|----------|---------|--------
# spatial/core/            |   100   |   100    |   100   |   100
# spatial/infrastructure/  |   92.5  |   90.1   |   94.2  |   92.8
# spatial/application/     |   87.3  |   85.6   |   89.1  |   87.5
# spatial/ui/              |   82.1  |   78.9   |   84.3  |   82.6
```

### 3. Test Scenarios

**Core Domain:**
- [x] SpatialQuery serialization/deserialization
- [x] Validation with all error cases
- [x] Compilation with metadata
- [x] Query hashing stability

**Infrastructure:**
- [x] SQL generation (spatial mode)
- [x] SQL generation (bbox fallback)
- [x] DuckDB execution (mocked)
- [x] Post-filtering logic
- [x] Cancellation handling

**Application:**
- [x] Service executeQuery success path
- [x] Service executeQuery error handling
- [x] Concurrent query cancellation
- [x] Query caching (hit/miss)
- [x] Event emission

**UI:**
- [x] Builder renders correctly
- [x] User input updates query
- [x] Run button triggers onRun callback
- [x] Error display
- [x] Loading states

**Integration:**
- [x] Complete query flow (validate → compile → execute → state update)
- [x] Concurrent edits (latest result wins)
- [x] State consistency (no drift)
- [x] Feature flag switching (old vs new)

**E2E:**
- [x] User selects point → sets distance → runs query → sees results
- [x] User adds exclude block → runs → sees filtered results
- [x] User submits invalid query → sees error message
- [x] Query executes in <500ms for typical dataset

### 4. Documentation

**Update/Create:**

#### AGENTS.md
Add section: "Spatial Module Architecture"
```markdown
## Spatial Module Architecture (Post-Refactor)

**Structure:**
```
spatial/
├── core/          - Pure domain logic (query, validator, compiler)
├── infrastructure/- SQL/DB (sql-builder, duckdb-runner)
├── application/   - Orchestration (spatial-service, executor, event-bus)
└── ui/            - Presentation (builder-ui, builder-state)
```

**Key Principles:**
1. Layers have clear boundaries (no circular dependencies)
2. Core domain is pure (no global state, testable)
3. Infrastructure accepts context (no global access)
4. Service orchestrates (handles concurrency, caching)
5. UI emits events (no business logic)

**Adding Features:**
1. Define in core domain (query model, validation)
2. Update infrastructure if needed (SQL generation)
3. Wire in service layer (orchestration)
4. Update UI (presentation)
5. Add tests at each layer
```

#### plan.md
Update discovery log:
```markdown
## Discovery log (2025-12-28)

Spatial query module refactored to layered architecture:
- Extracted core domain (query, validator, compiler) - pure logic, 100% tested
- Extracted infrastructure (sql-builder, duckdb-runner) - context-based, no global state
- Added service layer (spatial-service) - orchestration, concurrency, caching
- Refactored UI (builder-ui) - presentation only, event-driven
- Consolidated state (single state.spatial object)
- Achieved >90% test coverage
- Regression rate reduced from ~40% to <10%
- Development friction eliminated (time to add feature now <2h)

See SPATIAL_ARCHITECTURE_REVIEW.md for complete analysis.
```

#### New: SPATIAL_MODULE_GUIDE.md
```markdown
# Spatial Module Developer Guide

## Quick Start

**Adding a New Spatial Operator:**
1. Update query model (core/query.js)
2. Add validation rule (core/validator.js)
3. Update compiler (core/compiler.js)
4. Add SQL generation (infrastructure/sql-builder.js)
5. Update UI options (ui/builder-ui.js)
6. Add tests for each layer

**Running Spatial Queries:**
```javascript
import { SpatialQueryService } from "./spatial/application/spatial-service.js";

const service = new SpatialQueryService({ state, eventBus, db });

const result = await service.executeQuery({
  find: "routes",
  condition: "within",
  distance: 500,
  target: "selected_point"
});
```

## Architecture Overview
[Detailed architecture explanation]

## Testing
[How to test each layer]

## Common Patterns
[Code examples for common tasks]
```

### 5. Migration Checklist

**Complete before declaring done:**

- [ ] All unit tests passing (>90% coverage)
- [ ] All integration tests passing
- [ ] All E2E tests passing (added to CI)
- [ ] No browser console errors
- [ ] Feature flag removed (new architecture is default)
- [ ] Old code removed (builder.js, old runner.js, old sql.js)
- [ ] Compatibility adapter removed
- [ ] Documentation updated (AGENTS.md, plan.md, new guide)
- [ ] Performance validated (no regression)
- [ ] Regression rate measured (<10%)
- [ ] Success metrics achieved (see below)

### 6. Success Metrics

**Measure and document:**

#### Architectural Health
```bash
# Coupling (modules with global state access)
grep -r "import.*state.*manager" public/js/spatial/ | wc -l
# Target: <20% (3-4 files max, only where needed)

# Complexity
npm run complexity
# Target: All functions <10 cyclomatic complexity
```

#### Test Coverage
```bash
npm run test:coverage
# Target: >90% overall
```

#### Developer Experience
```bash
# Time to add feature (measure with timer)
# Add new operator "crosses_boundary"
# Target: <2 hours from start to tested

# Regression rate (count bugs introduced in last 10 PRs)
# Target: <10% (1 regression or less per 10 changes)
```

#### Performance
```bash
# Query execution time
console.time("spatial-query");
await service.executeQuery(query);
console.timeEnd("spatial-query");
# Target: <500ms for typical queries
```

**Document results in SPATIAL_REFACTOR_COMPLETE.md:**
```markdown
## Refactoring Complete - Success Metrics

**Achieved:**
- Test coverage: 92.3% (target: >90%) ✅
- Coupling: 15% (target: <20%) ✅
- Complexity: max 8 (target: <10) ✅
- Time to add feature: 1.5h (target: <2h) ✅
- Regression rate: 5% (target: <10%) ✅
- Query execution: 380ms avg (target: <500ms) ✅

**Before vs After:**
| Metric | Before | After | Improvement |
|--------|--------|-------|-------------|
| Test Coverage | ~50% | 92.3% | +84% |
| Regression Rate | ~40% | 5% | -87% |
| Time to Feature | Unpredictable | <2h | Consistent |
| Complexity (max) | 15 | 8 | -47% |
```

## Refactoring Practices

**CRITICAL - Follow AGENTS.md:**

1. **Test continuously:**
   ```bash
   # After adding each test file
   npm test -- <test-file>
   
   # Coverage after each batch
   npm run test:coverage
   ```

2. **Document as you go:**
   - Update AGENTS.md after each section
   - Update plan.md with discoveries
   - Create guide while knowledge is fresh

3. **Git commits:**
   ```bash
   git add tests/spatial/core/*.test.js
   git commit -m "Add comprehensive core domain tests (100% coverage)
   
   - SpatialQuery model tests
   - Validator tests (all error cases)
   - Compiler tests (caching, versioning)"
   
   git add tests/spatial/integration/*.test.js
   git commit -m "Add integration tests for complete query flow
   
   - Validate → compile → execute
   - Concurrent queries (cancellation)
   - State consistency checks"
   
   git add tests/e2e/spatial/*.e2e.js
   git commit -m "Add E2E tests for spatial queries
   
   - Point selection and query execution
   - Block operators
   - Error handling
   - Performance validation"
   
   git add AGENTS.md plan.md SPATIAL_MODULE_GUIDE.md
   git commit -m "Update documentation with new spatial architecture
   
   - AGENTS.md: module structure and principles
   - plan.md: discovery log updated
   - New developer guide created"
   ```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Test coverage >90% (verified with coverage report)
- [ ] All test levels passing (unit, integration, E2E)
- [ ] E2E tests added to CI (.github/workflows/ci.yml)
- [ ] Documentation complete (AGENTS.md, plan.md, new guide)
- [ ] Success metrics measured and documented
- [ ] Performance validated (no regression)
- [ ] Feature flag removed
- [ ] Old code removed
- [ ] Compatibility adapter removed
- [ ] SPATIAL_REFACTOR_COMPLETE.md created
- [ ] Committed and pushed

## References

SPATIAL_ARCHITECTURE_REVIEW.md section: "Testing Strategy"
AGENTS.md section: "Testing During Refactoring"

## Parent Epic

NetworkView-p5s (Spatial Query Module: Architectural Refactoring)

## Depends On

All previous phases (1-5)

## Completion Criteria

This phase completes the refactoring epic. After this:
- New architecture is production-ready
- Old code is removed
- Documentation is complete
- Success metrics prove improvement
- Team can confidently build on this foundation

title: Phase 5: Consolidate State Management (Single Source of Truth)
Clarify filter apply model (auto-apply vs Apply button)
description:
The UI presents an explicit "Apply filters" action, but filters auto-apply on change (debounced) for most controls. This creates a split mental model and makes it unclear when changes are live.

Context:
- Auto-apply debounce in public/app.js (filter change bindings).
- Apply button + Reset visible in public/index.html Actions section.

Acceptance criteria:
- Decide and document one model (explicit apply OR auto-apply) and align UI copy/behavior.
- If auto-apply: rename button to "Re-run" or "Apply now" and add an "Auto" indicator or toggle; add a brief hint near Actions.
- If manual apply: remove debounce auto-apply and show a "pending changes" indicator.
- Update status/preview messaging to match the chosen model.

Files:
- public/index.html
- public/app.js

title: Update UI filters to use multi-membership fields
description: Adjust map/table filtering to use la_codes/rpt_codes (contains match) with fallback to primary fields; update status/debug messaging.

title: Epic: Simplified Spatial Logic Builder
description:
Summary
Non-technical spatial logic builder for the Spatial Query Tool using Include / Also include / Exclude blocks. Translates to boolean internally, updates map/table live, and produces plain-English evidence.

Goals
- Usable by non-technical users in <60s
- Visual, guided, hard to break
- Explainable + exportable

Non-goals (v1)
- Full boolean expression editor
- Arbitrary spatial operators beyond curated list
- Teaching boolean terminology

Dependencies
- Spatial Query Tool epic (NetworkView-3uh)
- Map ↔ table linkage
- Evidence panel infrastructure

Source: Feature request (Simplified Spatial Logic Builder)

Implementation note: base the logic builder on a Python-backed runner (tarted-up python runner) so templates can be updated easily now and support user-defined templates later.

title: Phase 2: Virtualised table follow-ups (row height + paging)
description:
Context
- Data Inspector table uses scroll-window virtualisation (spacer rows + visible slice) and a configurable tableLimit (default 2000).

Problems
- Virtualisation assumes fixed row height; style/font changes can desync scroll math.
- Large selections still need paging/offset or adaptive limits to avoid heavy single-shot DuckDB queries.

Acceptance
- Measure row height dynamically (at least once per render) to keep spacer math accurate.
- Add paging (LIMIT/OFFSET) or adaptive tableLimit based on selection size/device to keep UI responsive for >10k rows.
- Selection, keyboard nav, and exports/evidence remain consistent under paging/virtualisation.

Implementation notes
- Files: public/app.js (renderTable + queryTable).
- Consider adding a per-query cache keyed by filter state to avoid requerying on scroll.

title: Implement DuckDB-based generation + refresh artifacts
description: Add a DuckDB spatial generation script to output routes.parquet/pmtiles with la_codes/rpt_codes; refresh metadata.json with thresholds and field definitions.

title: Improve spatial query coverage and relation controls
description:
## Summary
Spatial queries are still missing services outside the local area (e.g., Aberdeen returns only 65 routes, dropping long-distance coach services) and the UI only lets you pick a point+radius; there is no way to choose whether the query should intersect, contain, or follow another relation. We need a more dataset-agnostic spatial filter experience that surfaces the right results for coast-to-coast services and gives users control over the relation.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Spatial queries return the expected set of services even when the radius spans large areas (e.g., Aberdeen example should include long-distance coaches once filters are configured appropriately).
- Builder UI exposes a dropdown (or similar control) to choose the spatial relation for each block (intersect/within/contains/touches), with a clear label that isn’t tied to routes, and updates the compiled state accordingly.
- Query generator honors the selected relation when building DuckDB SQL, including geometry and bbox fallbacks, so the backend can handle intersect/within/contain/touch without leaking route-specific terms.
- Document the new choices in the viewer help text so users know what each relation does and how it affects long-distance matches.

## Dependencies
- Depends on NetworkView-3uh (Spatial Query Tool epic)

title: Phase 2: Service search (route number/name)
description:
Phase: Phase 2 — Map Viewer MVP (route lines + clip + filters + linked table) (5–10 days)
Section: filtering
Source: plan.md

title: Spatial point picker queries do not affect map/table (DuckDB spatial extension not loading)
description: Point-based spatial queries fail: pick point + within radius returns no results and does not filter map/table. Console shows 'st_point not in catalog' and spatial extension install/load errors, plus enable_external_access errors. This breaks SLB/Spatial Query Tool and regresses basic filters.
notes: RESOLVED with bbox fallback strategy. Created public/js/spatial/sql.js (230 lines) with expandPointToBbox, buildPointDistanceWhere, buildAttributeWhere, buildSpatialWhere. Updated public/js/spatial/runner.js to execute DuckDB queries using SQL generator. Wired onRun handler in app.js to use runner (lines 2946-2975). Bbox fallback uses min_lon, min_lat, max_lon, max_lat columns with approximate distance calculation (~111km per degree). Works immediately without spatial extension. Boundary operators (touches/inside) still require spatial extension and throw error if unavailable. See SPATIAL_EXTENSION_INVESTIGATION.md for full analysis. Next: test with real data, add UI messaging about approximation.

title: Boundary filters only match origin routes
description:
Summary
- LA/RPT boundary filters highlight a matching route set for one boundary code only (service start), so segments that also appear in the boundary but originate elsewhere never appear in filtered results.

Steps
1. Load the app with LA/RPT boundary filters enabled.
2. Pick a service that starts in Edinburgh but also passes through Aberdeen (or vice versa).
3. Apply the EDF boundary filter (Aberdeen or Edinburgh) and observe that the service appears only in its origin boundary and not in the other attachment even though the route passes through it.

Expected
- A route that intersects multiple boundary clips should appear in each clip where it has coverage (e.g., services touching both Edinburgh and Aberdeen shown when filtering either boundary).

Actual
- The map/table only show the route when filtering its start boundary; the same service disappears when filtering the destination or any additional boundary.

Notes
- This should match the real-world 1→many relationship between routes and boundaries.
- Likely a defect in the boundary match SQL or service_id join (current filters assume 1:1 origin match).
